title: What are the benefits of the philosophy of religion? - Quora

response.answer_text: Taking advantage of gulibility and superstition and fear of death, to increase the worldly wealth and power of a few.

The philosophy of a religion is just what the religion teaches. In practical terms. In the case of an ethnoreligion, it would be the cultural values of that ethnoreligious group. So Judaism has a very legalistic philosophy, because that’s how that group sees the world. In the case of an evangelical religion, it’s the philosophy espoused by the religion’s founder. So Christianity has a very merciful philosophy, turn the other cheek, judge not lest you be judged, gold rule, etc… In many ways your question is backwards. It’s not that the philosophy has a purpose to the religion. It’s that the religion has a purpose to the philosophy. The religion is a vehicle for the philosophy of the group/ founder, the means by which the philosophy is enforced.  Turn the other cheek.  Don’t fall into extremes.
